uniform_title_as_recorded: Lawāmiʻ al-asrār fī sharḥ Maṭāliʻ al-anwār
uniform_title_agr: لوامع الاسرار في شرح مطال الانوار
subject_as_recorded: Urmawī, Sirāj al-Dīn Maḥmūd ibn Abī Bakr, 1198-1283. Maṭāliʻ al-anwār|Logic--Early works to 1800|Islamic philosophy--Early works to 1800|Islamic philosophy|Logic
author_as_recorded: Quṭb al-Taḥtānī, Muḥammad ibn Muḥammad, 1294 or 1295-1364 or 1365
author_as_recorded_agr: قطب التحتاني، محمد بن محمد، 1294 ر 1295-1364 ر 1365
note: Copy completed in the hand of Aḥmad ibn Muḥammad ibn Aḥmad ibn al-Ḥājj Muḥammad al-Abzarī al-ʻAbbāsī al-Qurashī on 13 Rajab 898 [April 30, 1493].

Written in a medium-sized upright calligraphic minuscule, an early "Perlschrift".|There are 5 ornamental canon tables (others are missing), 4 headpieces with floral ornaments, 4 ornamented initials, and minor initials in gold on magenta ink.|Miniatures of the four evangelists (datable to the second half of the 12th century: see Vikan) were tipped into the ms. in ca. the 13th century, replacing sketches in brown ink facing the opening page of each gospel. The miniatures of Matthew and Mark are now shelved separately. That of John is now at Dumbarton Oaks, accession no. 58.105. That of Luke is missing.|Bound in modern white doeskin over thick boards, with 2 leather catches, now broken.|In 2 tray cases labelled "v. 1" for the ms. and "v. 2" for the 2 miniatures (foldered within the case); both 30 cm.|According to a subscription on f. 250r, the ms. was donated to the monastery of the Eleousa, or Nea Mone, by Konstantinos Angelos. The emperor Theodore Komnenos Laskaris is mentioned as having died, hence after 1222.

Page area 21 x 15 cm.; written area 16 x 10 cm.|Bookplate of former owner J. Rendel Harris with his number (24). Purchased by the Harvard Semitic Museum in 1905 (accession no. 3962).|Deposited by the Harvard Semitic Museum, ca. 1959.

Oriental binding in full leather, the spine renewed by a western binder.|Originally in quires of 10 leaves signed 1-9, but leaves are wanting before f. 1 and after ff. 1, 5, 13, 22, 33, 41, 80. Ff. 14, 23, 24, 34, 35, 42, 43, 81, 82 are blank leaves supplied by the binder.|Page size 18 x 13 cm; text area 14 x 9 cm.|With this is bound Stories of saints, [1448 or 1449].|Written in a clear bold serto hand, 13-16 lines per page, in black with rubrications.|Bookplate of former owner J. Rendel Harris with his number (26). Purchased by the Harvard Semitic Museum, 1905 (accession no. 3964).|Deposited by the Harvard Semitic Museum, ca. 1959.
Written in Kufic script black ink with red diacritics in the 5th century of the Hejiri era (circa 11th century CE).|Torn in one corner.|See curatorial file for more information.

title_as_recorded: Leaf from Ghistelles book of hours
physical_description: Extent: 1 leaf, unbound (.04 linear feet) : vellum ; 119 x 83 mm
note: Written in brown ink in a gothic book hand with rubrics and decorative pen work in red, blue, and gold. Also with seven one-line initials, three in blue with decorative pen work in red, and four in gold. Written in Southwest Flanders, circa 1299-1300.|Probably forms a part of a whole that would include MS Lat 446, Houghon Library.|In a protective case.|Purchased with th Sara Norton Bequest, 2017.

title_as_recorded: Leaf from Ghistelles book of hours
physical_description: Extent: 1 leaf, unbound (.04 linear feet) : vellum ; 121 x 84 mm
note: Written in brown ink in a gothic book hand with rubrics and decorative pen work in red, blue, and gold. Also with six one-line initials, four in blue with decorative pen work in red, and two in gold; one two-line initial in gold with blue, red, white, and gold decoration; a border of red, blue and gold. Border ends at top with the head of a lion and at bottom with a man playing a pipe. Written in Southwest Flanders, circa 1299-1300.|Probably forms a part of a whole that would include MS Lat 446.1, Houghon Library.|In a protective case.|Purchased with Henry Saltonstall Howe Fund, 2014.

author_as_recorded: Theodore, Bishop of Mopsuestia, approximately 350-428 or 429
note: Fragment written in France in a single column, 27 long lines, in brown ink in Merovingian minuscule of the Corbie tradition; with later running titles, probably 12th century.|Title supplied by cataloger.|Bound with a pamphlet stitch into a cloth folder.|Purchased with Bernard H. Breslauer Bequest, 2012.

physical_description: Extent: 566 leaves in 49 quires, unbound : vellum ; 37 centimeters.
note: Title supplied by cataloger.|Written in an unidentified hand in a bolorgir script in black ink, with red initials, marginal decoration in form of portraits of saints, and headpieces; pages appear slashed and also damaged by moisture, lacks beginning and end.|In a red cloth slipcase.|Deposted by Paul O. Boghossian, Jr., Mrs. A. Holopigian, Mrs. Peter R. Keeler, and Mrs. Ralph Seferian, 1965.

physical_description: Extent: 1 leaf (.04 linear ft.) : vellum ; 43 cm
note: Written in black ink in a gothic book hand in 2 columns with musical notation on a 4-line staff; with rubrics and initials in red and blue, including 2 illuminated and 1 historiated initials.|The illuminations are in the style of Villard de Honnecourt.|Formerly a part of the leaves now comprising MS Typ 120, with which it is housed and shelved.|In a tray case, 48 cm.|Purchased with the Arthur and Charlotte Vershbow Fund, 2013.|Formerly owned by Philip Hofer and held at Houghton Library in MS Typ 120H.

title_as_recorded: Here bygynneth a boke in englysche tonge that Þat ys called Brute of ynglonde
subject_as_recorded: Brutus, the Trojan (Legendary character)--Romances|Great Britain--History--To 1485--Early works to 1800
physical_description: Extent: 106 leaves, bound : vellum and paper, ill. ; 39 cm.
note: Written in an anglicana formata script in 2 columns of 45 lines; blank spaces for unilluminated initials, colored initials in blue and red with pen flourishes, headings in red. Written in England.|Partial leaf (f. 1r) contains grid filled with illustrated figures for lunar prognostication. Other leaves contain marginal drawings of grostesques, occupations of the months, coat of arms, and scenes of the Nativity and the Adoration of the Magi (f. 14r). Partially colored coat of arms, identified by family name appear on ff. 95r-105v.|Bound in 19th-cent. English blind-tooled brown goatskin.|In a tray case, 41 cm.|Bequest of William K. Richardson, 1951.

note: Written in bâtarde script in 1 column of 21 lines; 18 miniatures, numerous foliate borders and decorated initials. Richardson, 1951.|Belonged to Count MacCarthy-Reagh (inscribed, MS 2540); Sir Thomas Phillipps (inscribed, MS 2164); Richardson.

Schab (no. 189); bought by Richardson in 1940.

Written in a good serto hand with estrangela features, in two columns, 25 lines per column, in black with rubrics in red and green.|Purchased by the Harvard Semitic Museum in 1922 (accession no. 8375) from Dr. F. Grote.|Semitic Museum deposit, ca. 1959.

physical_description: Extent: 103 leaves, bound : vellum ; 31 cm. (1 volume)
note: Written in littera bastarda in two columns in brown ink, initial letters in red and blue with pen-work decoration. The decoration also includes 15 foliate borders and 15 illuminated initials.|Bound ca. 1901 in three volumes in red velvet.|In 3 tray cases, 50 cm.|Jean Duc de Berry (his arms, f. 1r); Sotheby's sales of 6 Aug. 1889 (lot 2762) and 26 Feb. 1900 (lot 224); Henry Yates Thompson (bookplate; his sale, Sotheby's, 23 Mar. 1920, II, lot 54); A. Chester Beatty (Beatty sale, London, Sotheby's 7 June 1932, I, lot 19).|Deposited by Philip Hofer, 1967; gift, 1982.

former_owner_as_recorded: Desportes, Philippe, 1546-1606|Meerman, Gerard, 1722-1771|Meerman, Johan, 1753-1815|Phillipps, Thomas, Sir, 1792-1872|Beatty, A. Chester Sir, 1875-1968|Collège de Clermont (Paris, France)

title_as_recorded: Letter from Pope Innocent IV to the Abbot and chapter of the Monastery of St. Berthin
note: Dated Lyon 7 March (non. Martii) in the 5th year of the pope's pontificate.|Written in a chancery hand in long lines in brown ink.|The seal shows "Innocentius PP IIII" on the obverse and the apostles Peter and Paul on the reverse. It is laced into the bottom of the document on a braided red and yellow cord.|Mounted and matted within a cloth folder, 36 x 35 cm.|In a cloth slipcase, 37 cm.|Purchased with the fund for Printing & Graphic Arts given by Philip Hofer, 1956.

Title from f. 1r: "Incipit liber qui vocatur Sompnium vurdavii".|The Latin text is written in littera bastarda in black ink in two columns, initials and paragraph marks in red and blue.|There are one large (f. 1r) and two small miniatures (3v, 73v).|Bound in 18th-century English mottled calf, gilt on spine.|In a tray case, 33 cm.|Longmans (cat. 1816, no. 6339); Thorpe (cat. 1823, no. 16348); Sir Thomas Phillipps (MS 253).|Deposited by Philip Hofer, 1967; bequeathed, 1984.

physical_description: Extent: 65 leaves, bound : vellum and paper ; 38 cm.
note: The Latin text is written in a large Italian rotunda hand in black and red, 10 lines per page. The ms. has lacunae after f. 30. title_as_recorded: Commissio Domini Gasparis de Molina Procuratoris S. Marci Mag. D. Thome, novissime electi super comissariis de Citra Canale
note: Written in a humanistic minuscule hand in brown ink in one column. Rubrics and 2-line initials are in red, blue, and gold.|The first page of text, f. 5r, has an ornamental border and miniature of Molina taking the oath of office administered by the Doge. Facing this is a motto and coat of arms.|Bound in contemporary red morocco, gilt. There were four ribbon ties or clasps, now perished.|In a tray case, 23 cm.|Purchased with the fund for Printing and Graphic Arts given by Philip Hofer, 1967.

title_as_recorded: Lectura arboris genealogiae regum Hispaniae; & specialiter in recta linea Regum Castellae et Legiois
note: Written in an upright roman hand in black ink in 2 columns, rubricated. Initial letters after the first page are only pencilled in or left as white space.|The author's name from a note at the end of the text, f. 105r. For the date 1492 see curatorial file. There are marginal notes in later hands, one datable to 1514-1517.|The frontispiece is an unidentified coat of arms, drawn in black ink.|Bound in original blind-tooled russet morocco over stout wooden boards. A chain is attached at the top of the front board.|In a tray case, 43 cm.|Bookplate of James William Ellsworth.|Deposited by Philip Hofer, 1967; bequeathed, 1984.

title_as_recorded: Catasticus sive repertorium bonorum ... Sancte Marie de Purcilia
subject_as_recorded: Abbazia di S. Maria di Porcilia (Padua, Italy)
note: Author's name from f. 1r and many attestations throughout the ms. usually beginning "Ego Antonius filius sapientis iuris periti domini francisci de conchellis".|Date from f. 1r. Entries continue in Antonius's hand down to 1524 (f. 58r).|Written in a small humanistic script in brown ink in one column. Initial letters are in burnished gold and colors.|F. 1r has a historiated border with the Camaldolese arms by Antonia Maria da Villafora.|Bound in modern vellum over thin boards.|In a tray case, 30 cm.|Deposited by Philip Hofer, 1967; bequeathed, 1984.

title_as_recorded: Grant of privileges to the brothers and sisters of the hospital of Halberstadt
physical_description: Extent: 1 leaf : vellum ; 19 x 27 cm. folded to 19 x 9 cm. +
note: The Latin text is written in a chancery hand in long lines in brownish ink.|The document is dated ii nonas August (i.e., 4 Aug.) in the first year of the Pope's pontificate, i.e. 1265. It is not signed.|The seal shows "Clemens PP IIII" on the obverse and the faces of SS. Peter and Paul on the reverse.|In a four-flap folder within a tray case.|Bequest of Philip Hofer, 1984.

Written and illuminated by Gottschalk for the Benedictine Abbey of Lambach In Austria.|For other leaves from this ms., including Houghton MS Typ 704 (5), see Davis, specif. 38-44.|The text is written in a carolingian minuscule hand in black ink, with unheightened neumes above the lines, also in black. Rubrics are in red.|The initial U of the antiphon "Veni sponsa Christi" is historiated in orange and purple, showing a crowned figure.|Bequest of Philip Hofer, 1984.

The Latin text is written in a tall documentary hand in brown ink in long lines, the initial word "Alexander" decorated with pen-work. The last line gives the place and date of writing: Anagni, 17 June 1161 ("15 kl. Jul anno secundo"). There is no signature. A seal, once affixed through slots in the vellum, is missing.|In a tray case, 31 cm.|Bequest of Philip Hofer, 1984.

physical_description: Extent: 85 leaves, bound : vellum, ill. ; 30 cm.
note: Written in humanistic script in 1 column of 26 lines; 1 small miniature, 1 historiated initial and 1 large frontispiece medallion in color and burnished gold; 1 inhabited white-vine border on f. 2r, 32 diagrams in gold, silver and colored inks, numerous decorated and colored initials in blue and red.|Written and illuminated in Italy (Florence?)|Title from frontispiece medallion.|Bound in original blind-tooled Italian red goatskin.|In a tray case, 33 cm.|Bequest of William K. Richardson, 1951.|Possibly belonged to Matthias Corvinus (based on an otherwise unrecorded royal emblem (f. 2r); Count Anton Apponyi of Vienna and Pressbourg, until 1817; Count Louis Apponyi; his sale (London, Sotheby's, 10 Nov. 1892, lot 9); bought by Quaritch; Robert Hoe; his sale (New York, Anderson, 8-12 Jan. 1912, II, lot 2417); bought by Richardson.

title_as_recorded: De celesti hierarchia; and other texts
note: Written in humanistic script by Ambrosius Camaldolensis in 1436 (explicit, f. 107v) with marginal annotations; 1 large frontispiece medallion with title in gilt and colors, 1 border and 5 initials in white-vine and gilt decoration, headings in pale rose.|Title from incipit.|Bound in late 19th-cent. blind-tooled citron morocco, gilt, by Leighton.|In a tray case, 32 cm.|Bequest of William K. Richardson, 1951.|Belonged to "CAR" in Venice, about 1540; George Dunn, Aug. 1907; his sale (London, 2 Feb. 1914, II, n. 1015); to Leighton; his sale (London, 14 Nov. 1918, I, n. 261); to Maggs; Maggs, cat. 374 (1918), n. 183, cat. 380 (1919), n. 1666, cat. 395 (1920), n. 32, cat. 404 (1921), n. 46; to Richardson.

subject_as_recorded: Cistercians--Discipline and government--Early works to 1800|Cistercians--Privileges and immunities--Early works to 1800
physical_description: Extent: 1 leaf : vellum ; 33 x 59 cm. folded to 12 x 30 cm. +
note: The Latin text is written in a chancery hand in long lines in brown ink.|Dated from the Lateran basilica, 15 kal. Ianr. in the 8th year of the pope's pontificate, i.e. 18 Dec. 1302.|Unsigned.|The seal shows "Bonifatius VIII" on the obverse and the faces of SS. Peter and Paul on the reverse.|In a three-flap folder within a tray case.|Bequest of Philip Hofer, 1984.

Written in a professional italic hand in brown ink, each line of verse beginning with a gold initial letter.|Title from title page of the printed edition (Rome 1573). The ms. has the same dedication to Pope Gregory XIII with date 1572 (f. 1v), and on f. 2r the same caption as the printed edition, but no title page.|Bound in 19th-century calf with panels from original gilt red morocco binding set into front and back covers.|In a tray case, 25 cm.|Bookplate of Walter Sneyd.|Purchased with the Price Greenleaf fund, 1904.

subject_as_recorded: Job (Biblical figure)--Sermons--Early works to 1800|Charity--Early works to 1800
note: Translations made by Hilary a monk of Verona and dedicated to Pope Sixtus IV (title page: "per Hilarionem monachum Veroneum traductus ad Sanctissimum Dnm N. Sistum IIII Pont. Max.")|Written in an upright humanisitic roman hand in one narrow column in black ink.|There are 1 large and 2 smaller foliate initials in tempera and gold. On f. 2r a drawing of the papal arms has been effaced.|Bound in Italian brown calf, ca. 1530, tooled in blind and gilt and stamped with a plaquette on front and back.|In a tray case, 19 cm.|Signature of Radulphus Sandras (?; 16th-cent.) on front pastedown.|Bequest of Charles Sumner, 1874.

title_as_recorded: Chronicles, a treatise on planets, and poems
subject_as_recorded: Caesar, Julius|History, Ancient--Chronology--Early works to 1800|Popes--Early works to 1800|Spain--History--Gothic period, 414-711
note: Written in humanistic cursive script by "Laurentius in Monte Sancte Marie in Cassiano" in 1408 (f. 83r); colored initials, headings and paragraph marks in red.|Title supplied by cataloger.|Bound in mid-19th-cent. red half calf with mottled paper over boards and marbled endpapers.|In a tray case, 31 cm.|Belonged to Paul Edouard Didier, comte de Riant.|Gift of J. Randolph Coolidge and Archibald Cary Coolidge, 1899.

title_as_recorded: Publii Terentii Afri clarissimi poetae comici liber
note: "Scriptum Ferrarie Anno MCCCCLXIII indictione undecima die Sabati xvii. mensis Decembr. hora xvi diei" - f. 92r. The writing is an upright humanistic minuscule in one column, in brownish ink with red rubrics, the initial letters of each line separated. (For other mss. by this scribe see De la Mare.) Major initials are in blue and red. Variant readings are written small in the margins.|The title page has a gilt white-vine part-border (incorporating an empty roundel), and there are 7 other illuminated initials in the same style.|Bound in 19th-century mottled sheepskin.|In a tray case, 29 cm.|Gift of Philip Hofer, 1956.

former_owner_as_recorded: Augustus Frederick, Prince, Duke of Sussex, 1773-1843|Maskell, William, 1814?-1890|Norton, Charles Eliot, 1827-1908|Ruskin, John, 1819-1900
physical_description: Extent: 423 leaves, bound : vellum, ill. ; 20 cm.
note: Written in a formal gothic script in Ghent, Belgium, and decorated with 15 historiated initials, probably at the Benedictine abbey of St. Peter of Mont-Blandin, near Ghent.|Bound in 18th-cent. Belgian (?) blind-tooled mottled brown calf.|In a protective tray case, 22 cm.|Belonged to the Benedictine abbey of St. Peter of Mont-Blandin, near Ghent (partially erased ex libris, f. 1r: "Sancti Petri in Blandino iuxta Gandavum"; in an unidentified English sale, ca. 1830, no. 13; bookplate with arms and motto of Augustus Frederick, Duke of Sussex (MS VI.H.h.15); bookplate of William Maskell; John Ruskin (inscribed, front flyleaf); gift from Ruskin to Charles Eliot Norton.|Purchased with funds from the Friends of the Library, 1905.

physical_description: Extent: 1 leaf : vellum ; 35 x 27 cm. mounted to 40 x 31 cm.
note: Written in a gothic book hand in two columns in black ink with red rubrics.|The recto has a 9-line historiated initial showing St. Ulric in vestments, holding a crozier and a fish. There is an elaborate floral border decoration in shades of green, incorporating an unknown coat of arms and inhabited by birds and an archer, on a ground of incised gold.|Mounted on a larger paper leaf. The verso is not visible.|Bequest of Philip Hofer, 1984.

former_owner_as_recorded: Morse, William Inglis, 1874-1952|San Pedro de Roda (Monastery : Puerto de la Selva, Spain)
physical_description: Extent: 48 leaves, bound : vellum, ill. ; 24 cm.
note: Written in a gothic hand in black ink in two columns, the first letter of each line highlighted in red. At the head of each column is space for an illustration. These spaces are filled with 75 pen and ink drawings as far as f. 22v; the rest are blank.|Bound in late 15th-century calf, tooled with an ornamental roll in blind.|In a tray case, 25 cm.|Written in Germany or Austria. The illustrations are later than the writing, ca. 1400.|Monastery of San Pedro de Roda; bought from Carlos-Tolrá by William Inglis Morse in 1943 and presented by him.

title_as_recorded: Missal with part of a breviary and other prayers
note: The ms. is assembled from fragments. Ff. 10-24 at least might be from a different ms. (see Light, 26).|Written in Italy, in minuscule hands of several sizes in brown ink in one column, initials in red.|F. 1r and 1v have large white-vine decorated initials in orange, green and brown.|Bound in ca. 1955 (some leaves being rearranged) in plain red leather.|In a tray case, 26 cm.|Purchased with the fund for Printing and Graphic Arts given by Philip Hofer, 1956.

Title from spine.|French, perhaps from Rouen.|Written in a humanistic book script in black ink, with many illuminated initials and line-endings.|At the beginning of the text ("fo. I" in the original foliation) there is a miniature of a bishop in a church performing the rite of dedication. Opposite is a drawing of the arms of a bishop in the Potier de La Morandière family, added later.|Later binding in red morocco, gilt.|In a tray case, 29 cm.|Rev. Henry Drury (his sale, London, 19 Feb. 1827, lot 3858); bought by Clarke; Earl Brownlow, Belton House (bookplate; his sale, London, Sotheby's 15 Apr. 1929, lot 745). Bought by Philip Hoferfrom Maggs and presented in 1942.

title_as_recorded: Triomphi del Petrarcha; Canzoni di Dante Allighieri poeta fiorentino
physical_description: Extent: 1 v. (49, 38 leaves) : vellum, paper ; 22 cm.
note: Written in an unidentified hand in gothic book hand with humanistic features. Only the outside bifolium of the Trionfi is vellum; remaining quires are paper. Vinestem decorated gold initial and top marginal border and wreath with coat of arms [Buondelmonti?] and floral scroll decoration appear on f. 1r; red and blue initials with pen decorations begin each chapter division; headings in pale red.|Written in Central Italy (Florence?), dated 1463 Feb. 14 (f. 49v) and 1463 Mar. 24 (f. 88).|Titles from colophons.|Bound in contemporary blind-stamped goat over wooden boards; remains of two clasps.|In a tray case, 23 cm.|Gift of Charles Eliot Norton (A.B., 1846), 1885.|Possibly belonged to a member of the Buondelmonti family; Tomaso Bernardino Braccioli of Cortona by 1552 (inscription, f. 49v: "Thomae Bernardini Braccioli Cortonensis et suorum amicorum, anno 1552, m. u. 6., 29 de decemb. 1552" and f. 88: "Thomae Bernardini Braccioli".

title_as_recorded: Great bull addressed to Abbot Lambert of the Monastery of St. Bertin
physical_description: Extent: 1 leaf : vellum ; 63 x 47 cm. folded to 16 x 24 cm.
note: Written in a papal chancery hand in brown ink in long lines. At the bottom are the rota, autograph signature of Pope Paschal, "Bene Valete" device, and datum line.|At the bottom is part of the cord formerly attaching the seal, but the seal itself is missing.|In a four-flap folder within a tray case, 18 x 26 cm.|Gift of Harrison D. Horblit, in memory of his son Mark M. Horblit, II.

title_as_recorded: Works and days; The shield of Heracles ; Theogony
note: Written by 6 scribes, in scholarly cursive scripts, in medium and dark brown inks, titles and initials in red.|A few initials are pen-ornamented. There are crude drawings on ff. 67r and 198v.|Copied probably in Italy and possibly in Terra d'Otranto (cf. MS Bodley Gr. class. e. 17).|Bound in contemporary limp goatskin.|In a tray case, 24 cm.|Signature "Joannis Baptistae Rotae" on f. 1r.|Purchased with the Constantius fund, 1942.

title_as_recorded: Comentum Macrobii Ambrosii in somnium Scipionis
note: Written in a humanistic hand in brown ink in one column. Many initial letters are illuminated, 2 with gilt and white-vine decoration. There are marginal diagrams in red and blue.|There are 2 full-page miniatures in gold and colors (ff. 2v, 3r), both showing the celestial spheres.|Contemporary binding in full leather, tooled in blind, over wooden boards. There were 2 clasps, now missing.|In a tray case, 28 cm.|Nicolai Briganti (16th or 17th century); Castellucci family (18th century). Purchased from Erwin Rosenthal with the Hofer fund, 1946.

genre_as_recorded: Byzantine chants|Manuscripts, Medieval--1100-1150|Manuscripts, Medieval--1150-1200|Manuscripts, Medieval--1200-1250|Manuscripts, Medieval--1250-1300|Manuscripts, Medieval--1300-1350|Rules (layout features)
former_owner_as_recorded: North, Frederick, Earl of Guilford, 1766-1827|Phillipps, Thomas, Sir, 1792-1872
note: Date from palaeography. The ms. was written by three different scribes in turn, the last one named in the colophon (f. 278r) as Theodosius, a Reader.|There is musical notation throughout, "middle Byzantine" for the main text, with revisions in the "late Byzantine" notation of the 14th century.|There are rectangular headpieces on ff. 1r, 269r, and other small ornaments throughout, all in red. Initials are in red with simple pen-work decoration.|Two flyleaves come from a 13th-century text discussing luxurious clothing.|The two pastedowns come from a martyrology of the 12th or 13th century.|Bound in 1632 in full leather over heavy wooden boards, tooled in blind. On the front is a panel showing David playing a harp; on the back, a floral ornament. There are two clasps of plaited leather and brass. The date of the binding comes from a note by the hieromonk Leontios on the front pastedown.|There are various notes by owners on the front and back pastedowns.|In a tray case, 29 cm.|Frederick North, Earl of Guilford (Guilford sale, Evans, 8 Dec. 1830, lot 236); Sir Thomas Phillipps (MS 7506, number pasted on spine).|Purchased with the Susan A. E. Morse fund, 1973.

title_as_recorded: The Psalms in Greek, with apparatus of other texts
note: Written by one scribe in a medium-sized calligraphic liturgical minuscule ("hieratic Perlschrift") with slight inclination to the right, typical of mss. of this date.|Date from the beginning date in the Easter tables.|There are 3 full-page miniatures (ff. 8v, 215v, 216v), three headpieces (2 with figural decoration), one anthropomorphic initial letter, and many pen-ornamented initials.|Bound in early 19th-century Russian tan leather.|In a tray case, 27 cm.|Michael Kantakouzenos (ownership inscription dated 1589 on front flyleaf) -- Edward Everett (purchased in Constantinople, 1819).|Gift of Edward Everett, 1820.

genre_as_recorded: Manuscripts, Renaissance--Italy--1500-1550|Calligraphy--Italy--16th century|Writing books--Italy--16th century|Penmanship specimen books--Italy--16th century
former_owner_as_recorded: Penny, Stephen|Raleigh, Edward|Hoby, Thomas Posthumus, Sir|Harford, Charles Joseph|Sydenham, Philip
physical_description: Extent: 1 v. (2, 20, 2 leaves): vellum and paper ; 15 x 21 cm.
note: The original ms. is on 20 vellum leaves. Paper leaves at the front and back contain ownership inscriptions and notes in English.|The specimens (verses from Ariosto, Orlando Furioso) are written in Italian in brown ink with some letters in gold ink. The writing is in an italic hand with many swash letters. Alternate rectos and versos are used.|"Bennardino Cataneo Scrivea al Signor Odoardo Ralyg Gentilhuomo Inglese" (5r). "Di Siena el di IIII di Febrraro MDXLV" (13r).|Bound in original brown morocco, gilt, by the "Venetian apple bindery", and stamped "Odoardo Ralygh".|In a tray case, 17 cm.|Edward Raleigh; Sir Posthumus Hoby (inscription, f. 1r); Philip Sydenham; Stephen Penny; C. J. Harford (bookplate; gift to him from Stephen Penny, 1779; sale, London, 1933, lot 359).|Gift of Dr. Myron A. Hofer in honor of Philip Hofer, 1981.

physical_description: Extent: 378 leaves, bound : vellum, ill. ; 11 cm. (1 volume)
note: Written in Germany for use in a Benedictine monastery in a hybrida script, with three miniatures (front pastedown, ff. 193v, 377v) drawn in pen, ink, and color wash on paper.|In a 15th-century German leather binding over beech boards with blind tooling and metalwork ornaments.|In a protective tray case, 18 cm.|See curatorial file for fragments of the manuscript removed and conserved during end-processing.|Formerly owned by W. F. Olis who bought the breviary in Paris in 1858; given to Samuel Eliot, grandfather of donor.|Gift of Samuel Eliot Morison, 1926.

title_as_recorded: Liber sextus Decretalium, with the glosses of Joannes Andreae
subject_as_recorded: Canon law--Early works to 1800|Canon law--Commentaries--Early works to 1800
note: The text of the decretals is written in the center of the page in a rotunda gothic book hand in two columns, surrounded by the commentary in a smaller hand in the same style, also in two columns.|F. 1r has a historiated border with unidentified arms. There are 44 historiated initials, mostly with men's heads. Many other initials are illuminated in colors and gold, or are in red or blue with pen-work decoration.|There are marks of the "correctores peciarii" (official inspectors of ms. textbooks at the University of Bologna), written very small, e.g. for the text on ff. 69r, 82v, etc. and for the gloss on ff. 10v, 13v, etc. See curatorial file for details.|The upper half of f. 3 has been cut away.|Bound in 15th-century Spanish brown morocco tooled in blind, with brass bosses and clasps.|In a tray case, 52 cm.|Purchased with the fund for Printing and Graphic Arts given by Philip Hofer, 19

title_as_recorded: Les diz moraulx des philosophes; translattez de lattin en francois par noble homme Messire Guillemme de Tignonville
former_owner_as_recorded: Backhouse, John Henry|Barclay, J. A. J
note: Written in littera bastarda in 1 column in brown ink, with many 1-line illuminated initials in the text.|There are 16 oblong miniatures in tempera and gold, by the workshop of the Master of the Harvard Hannibal.|At least 5 leaves are missing, including some replaced by blanks after ff. 6 and 10.|Bound in olive green morocco ca. 1830.|In a tray case, 33 cm.|John Henry Backhouse (bookplate); J. A. J. Barclay (bookplate).|Deposited by Philip Hofer, 1967; bequeathed, 1984.

The biblical text is written in a formal minuscule hand in black ink in a central column of varying width and in a varying number of lines per page. Initial letters are in red and blue. The gloss in a smaller script is arranged in columns flanking the biblical text and between the lines.|There is one illuminated initial, f. 2r.|Written in Paris, or in Austria: see Light, 87-8.|Bound in 13th-century brown morocco with all-over blind-stamping.|In a tray case, 29 cm.|Formerly MS 347 in the library of the Abbey of St. Blaise, Admont, Austria (ms. note tipped onto front flyleaf; library stamps on ff. 2, 73).|Gift of Philip Hofer in honor of William A. Jackson, 1955.

artist_as_recorded: Marmion, Simon, 1420-1489|Louthe Master|Master of the Dresden Hours, active 1470-1500|Master of the Houghton Miniatures|Ghent Associates of the Master of Mary of Burgundy
former_owner_as_recorded: White, Alfred Tredway, 1846-1921|Van Sinderen, Adrian, 1887-1963|Quaritch, Bernard, 1819-1899|Stirling Maxwell, William, 1818-1878|White, William Augustus, 1843-1927|Emerson, Frances White, 1860-1957
note: The text is written in a gothic rotunda book-hand in one column.|Each page has an outer border panel in tempera and gold in trompe-l'oeil style. Many pages have full borders in this style. There are also 7 miniatures, 14 historiated borders, 28 historiated initials, and 24 calendar illustrations in tempera and gold. (At least 23 further miniatures originally in the ms. are now missing.) The illuminators include the Master of the Houghton Miniatures (named for this ms.), the Ghent Associates of the Master of Mary of Burgundy, the Louthe Master or Simon Marmion, and the Master of the Dresden Prayerbook.|Evidence formerly cited (see Quaritch) to show that the book was written for Queen Juana la Loca of Castile is now interpreted differently.|The texts for the various votive masses are on ff. 51-69 and 128-132.|Both volumes are bound by Zaehnsdorf ca. 1886 in black morocco with an all-over pattern of flowers and the monogram y y.|Vol. 1 has a cloth back and is in a black morocco tray case, vol. 2 in a blue morocco pull-off case, both 16 cm.|The main text of the ms. is in Latin, but at the end (ff. 245v-248r) is "la oracion de Sant Gregorio Papa" in Spanish.|Bernard Quaritch (the whole ms. in 1 volume); Sir William Stirling Maxwell (Quaritch catalogue Sept. 1886 no. 35696), who rebound it in 2 vols.; Quaritch (both vols.)|Vol. 1 (MS Typ 443): William A. White, 1892; his daughter Mrs. Frances White Emerson.|Vol. 1 given in memory of William A. White and his daughter Frances White Emerson by members of their family: Harold White, Donald Moffat, and Mrs. John Wing, 1958.|Bernard Quaritch (the whole ms. in 1 volume); Sir William Stirling Maxwell (Quaritch catalogue Sept. 1886 no. 35696), who rebound it in 2 vols.; Quaritch (both vols.)|Vol. 2 (MS Typ 443.1): Alfred T. White, 1892; his son-in-law Adrian Van Sinderen.|Vol. 2 deposited by Mrs. Adrian Van Sinderen, 1966.

title_as_recorded: Epistles of classical Greek authors in Latin translation
note: Written in an upright humanistic hand in black ink by Gundisalvus Hispanus.|There are 4 white-vine illuminated borders and initials by Mariano del Buono.|Bound in original blind-tooled brown morocco.|Identifications of the scribe and illuminator by A. de la Mare.|In a tray case, 23 cm.|Deposited by Philip Hofer, 1967; bequeathed, 1984.

Written in a medium-sized upright calligraphic minuscule, an early "Perlschrift".|There are 5 ornamental canon tables (others are missing), 4 headpieces with floral ornaments, 4 ornamented initials, and minor initials in gold on magenta ink.|Miniatures of the four evangelists (datable to the second half of the 12th century: see Vikan) were tipped into the ms. in ca. the 13th century, replacing sketches in brown ink facing the opening page of each gospel. The miniatures of Matthew and Mark are now shelved separately. That of John is now at Dumbarton Oaks, accession no. 58.105. That of Luke is missing.|Bound in modern white doeskin over thick boards, with 2 leather catches, now broken.|In 2 tray cases labelled "v. 1" for the ms. and "v. 2" for the 2 miniatures (foldered within the case); both 30 cm.|According to a subscription on f. 250r, the ms. was donated to the monastery of the Eleousa, or Nea Mone, by Konstantinos Angelos. The emperor Theodore Komnenos Laskaris is mentioned as having died, hence after 1222.

Written possibly by Sigismondo de Sigismondi, in a small upright humanistic hand in brownish ink, 18 lines per page the initial letters of each line separated into the margin.|The initial leaf of each satire has a miniature in the lower margin and a border, and the first letter of the text in gold. On f. 1v is a miniature of the poet reading his work, and on f. 2r a historiated initial showing the poet. This page-opening has a border with medallions and an unidentified coat of arms. The style of illumination is like that of Monte and Gherardo del Fora. (See curatorial file.)|Bound in old velvet over boards, edges gilt and gauffered.|In a cloth folder within a slipcase, 13 cm.|Thomas E. Marston (bookplate; his sale, London, Sotheby's 11 Dec. 1961, lot 192).|Deposited by Philip Hofer, 1967; bequeathed, 1984.
English translation in an unknown hand.|Bound in contemporary limp vellum.|In a tray case, 38 cm.|Purchased with the Amy Lowell fund, 1956.

title_as_recorded: Triumphs of the gentlewomen of Bologna
note: Title supplied by cataloger. According to the letter, the poem is the third canto of a longer poem. Cf. "Fine del terzo canto" (f. 18r).|The poem begins "O che dolce gioir, che gran dolcezza, saria d'un huom ch'innamorato vive" and ends "Quando de le Sibille i ricchi fregi, i triomphi gl'honor, la gloria, e i pregi."|The frontispiece is a colored drawing showing the three Graces and Mercury introducing the ten Sybils to Jupiter.|Written in a calligraphic italic hand in brown ink.|Bound in 17th-century vellum.|In a tray case, 26 cm.|Signatures of C. Bruscoli (dated Florence 1935) and G[iuseppe] Martini.|Deposited by Philip Hofer, 1967; bequeathed, 1984.

title_as_recorded: Scelta delle più belle, e più artificiose forme di lettere c'hoggidi da molti eccellenti scrittori d'Italia son poste in uso
genre_as_recorded: Manuscripts, Renaissance--Italy--1550-1600|Penmanship specimen manuals--Italy--16th century|Writing books--Italy--16th century
physical_description: Extent: 14 leaves, bound : vellum ; 20 x 26 cm.
note: Writing specimens in a variety of roman, italic and chancery scripts in brown ink. Up to f. 10 each specimen is on a separate page within an elaborate pen-drawn border.|Bound in 19th-century brown paste paper over boards.|Deposited by Philip Hofer, 1967; bequeathed, 1984.

title_as_recorded: Panegyricus ad Leonardum Lauretanum Venetorum Principem Illustrissimum
note: Written by the author in an upright italic hand in black ink in one column.|The title page (f. 2r) is in all capitals, in colors, incorporating an illuminated initial and foliate decoration with the arms of Doge Leonardo Loredano.|Bound in 19th-century English blue calf.|Walter Sneyd (bookplate); John Burns (signature dated [18]92).|Deposited by Philip Hofer, 1967; bequeathed, 1984.

author_as_recorded: Jacobus, Mediolanensis, active 13th century|Bonaventure, Saint, Cardinal, approximately 1217-1274
note: The work Stimulus amoris or stimulus divini amoris was traditionally attributed to St. Bonaventure; given to Cardinal Nicolò Albergati (Bond and Faye).|Each of the two works is written in a different Italian gothic book hand in 1 column.|There are 2 miniatures and foliate borders incorporating the arms ofa cardinal (ff. 1r, 90r). Fol. 90r has a historiated initial, and there are many illuminated initial letters.|Bound in original blind-stamped brown calf, with 4 clasps.|In a tray case, 20 cm.|Deposited by Philip Hofer, 1967; bequeathed, 1984.

title_as_recorded: Sydrac et Bocthus; le livre de Sydrac de toute sciences
former_owner_as_recorded: Bateman, Richard Thomas, 1712 or 1713-|Suchier, Hermann, 1848-1914|Olschki, Leo S. 1861-1940
note: Leaves 1-159r contain Livre de Sydrac; leaves 159r-160v contain Raoul de Houdenc's Roman des eles de courtoisie (a fragment of 252 lines).|Manuscript in a gothic book hand in red and blue ink, in two columns, with decorated initials in red and blue and 9 illuminated initials with burnished gold and extensions (leaves 13, 15, 22, 34v, 85, 105v, 109, 125v, and 137; blank space for possible initial on leaf 122).|Written in Northern France, not earlier than 1300 and probably ca. 1320.|Limp vellum cover with separate (later?) vellum strip pasted over spine; pastedowns are from a much larger manuscript (13th cent., in Latin, on a legal topic, main text in two columns, with glosses and red and blue paragraph marks).|Title from front cover.|Sydrac incipits: Chi commencent le capitre et les questions (leaf 1) and La pourveanche nostre Signeur le pere tout pouissant (leaf 13); explicit, Sydrac nous ensengne et monstre [à l'?]honneur Dou cors et pourfit des ames. amen (leaf 159).|Sydrac text differs greatly from that published in Sylvie-Marie Steiner, Le livre de Sidrach ([Melun, France]: Association Mémoires, 1994).|Gift of David P. Wheatland, 1991.|Purchased by Wheatland from H.P. Kraus; Leo Olschki (1920); Herman Suchier (1896); bookplate of Nicolas Joseph Foucault; leaf one annotated: "OR.F Bateman's Sale 1774" (identified in dealer's note as the 1774 May 3 Christie's sale of the library of the Hon. Richard Bateman); annotation on Foucault bookplate: "J A Fox [Jc] Bacon [or Becan?] Auction April 29, 1777 Pr -.8.0"; ownership(?) mark erased on leaf 1: "[ ]23 1782".
